posts.title: There is no presidential immunity for treason for former presidents. While the Supreme Court has affirmed that presidents have immunity for "official acts" while in office, this immunity does not extend to criminal prosecution for treason or other crimes, especially after leaving office.

posts.raw_content:
**"A Devastating Blow": HSI Arrests at Argentine Restaurants**  
*"They should focus on more important things than arresting people who make empanadas," said the business owner.*  
Istra Pacheco, EL VOCERO, 07/26/2025  

The restaurants Viejo Almacén and Piccolino suffered a “devastating blow” on Thursday afternoon with the arrest of nearly twenty individuals suspected of being in Puerto Rico with undefined immigration status, according to the business owner, Adrián Romano.

In disbelief and indignation, the entrepreneur recounted that over 100 federal agents from the Office of Homeland Security Investigations (HSI) stormed seven establishments simultaneously—six restaurants and a central kitchen where pasta is made, meats are cut, and desserts are prepared, among other tasks—with “disproportionate violence.”

“I’m devastated for the 17 families that have been destroyed, torn apart, people whose dreams have been shattered, who are only seeking a better life,” he said in a phone interview. Taking a deep breath and with a trembling voice, he continued: “But we have to keep working because over a hundred other families depend on us. Still, what happened is abusive. There’s no need to send 100 aggressive agents to a workplace.”

The arrests took place at Viejo Almacén and Piccolino. Romano stated, “I know what it’s like to be treated like a criminal. Those arrested are handcuffed, put in a cage, denied visits, food, or blankets, and treated like drug traffickers when, in reality, they come from devastated countries like mine, in crisis, seeking a better life. These are people just trying to earn a living.” [Argentina is doing fine, you prick. And how many of your slaves are really from there?]

Romano, an Argentine by birth but a resident of Puerto Rico for about 25 years, said his children are Puerto Rican, and while he feels part of the community, he remains an immigrant himself. He noted that the atmosphere among workers remains tense, emphasizing that these are people who work 10 to 12 hours together, forming bonds of friendship and family.

According to Romano, nearly 24 hours after the HSI intervention, some of the detained individuals had been released because they were legally married to U.S. citizens or were in the process of obtaining documentation.

He pointed out that since the COVID-19 pandemic, Puerto Rico has faced a labor shortage crisis, making these arrests inexplicable. “There needs to be a solution because there really aren’t enough people to work. It’s a reality. Anyone living here can see it—go to a gas station, a restaurant, a mechanic, any business, and you’ll see signs saying, ‘Now hiring.’ We’re seeing billboards from big companies offering jobs at $12 an hour or more. It’s the truth. I consider what they’re doing to us very unfair,” he stated. [There is a solution. Pay a living wage and use e-Verify.]

Romano rejected the notion that employers prioritize hiring foreigners on a whim or to pay them less. “That’s not true. The HSI chief I spoke with said we exploit people, but that’s not the case. Ask anyone. No one earns less… we’re a company that gives opportunities,” he said. [Suuuuure.]

He noted that his business operates in the food sector and generates jobs, which benefits the economy. Romano said he is working with his lawyer to “see how we can resolve this situation.” [Stop hiring illegals and that resolves it.] Additionally, among his employees are minimum-security inmates or those in transitional housing programs, as part of collaborative agreements with federal and state authorities.

He also pointed out that, given the high levels of violence, drug trafficking, and weapons smuggling in Puerto Rico, authorities should focus their resources on addressing those issues. “They should focus on more important things than arresting people who make empanadas,” he expressed.

For her part, Rebecca González, the special agent in charge of HSI’s Puerto Rico office, stated in a press release that the search warrant executed at the seven establishments sought evidence related to the facilitation, transportation, harboring, or concealment of foreigners known to have entered or remained in the United States illegally, as well as the knowing employment of individuals without legal work authorization, in violation of U.S. immigration laws.

“This operation is part of an ongoing investigation led by Homeland Security Investigations (HSI), with support from our federal and local partners. Our mission is to uphold the integrity of immigration law, ensure compliance with labor regulations, and protect the community from organizations that exploit vulnerable populations. The investigation remains active, and no further details will be released at this time,” she stated.

[Translation mine] 

Sauce: https://www.elvocero.com/ley-y-orden/golpe-baj-simo-arrestos-de-hsi-en-restaurantes-argentinos/article_bf8478f5-29af-461c-90fe-464bbc9c49ea.html
posts.author: BoricuaPede
posts.title: ICE busts up a group of seven restaurants with a raid involving over 100 agents...modern slaveholder big sad, of course.
